did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Dr. Jimmye S. Hillman Papers contain writings, presentations, and speeches during his career as a professor of agricultural economics at the University of Arizona as well as a consulting economist for several committees and organizations.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on this collection.

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Dr. Jimmye S. Hillman (MS 569). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dr. Jimmye S. Hillman (1923 – 2015), was a long-time professor at the University of Arizona - College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, an international economist, as well as a literary memoirist later in life.

Hillman was born in 1923 and grew up in Greene County, Mississippi on a subsistence farm. After graduating from Mississippi State University in 1942, Hillman served in the United States Army from 1942 to 1945, obtained a Master’s Degree from Texas A & M University in 1946, and a Ph.D. in agricultural economics from University of California, Berkeley, in 1950. Hillman joined the UA faculty in 1950, became head of the Department of Agricultural Economics in 1961, serving in that role until his retirement in 1990.

While at UA, Hillman trained generations of agricultural economists and took part in making the University a leader in the field. His research interests included agricultural and trade policies with some of his most significant work centered on the study of nontariff trade barriers. He authored two books, Nontariff Agricultural Trade Barriers (1978) and Technical Barriers to Agricultural Trade (1991), as well as numerous articles examining the globalization of food production and consumption, the proliferation of new food technologies, and the effects of agribusiness and technology on the environment, human health and social justice.

Additionally, he served as economist for the U.S. Agency for International Development in Brazil from 1957-1959, developed USAID Green Revolution projects in the Cape Verde Islands, and served as an advisor on agricultural policy to the government of Portugal when the nation was preparing to enter the European Union. In 1966-1967, Hillman was the Executive Director of the President's National Advisory Commission on Food and Fiber, appointed by President Lyndon Johnson, and in 1983-1984, chaired the agricultural study group assisting the President's Commission on United States-Japanese Relations, under President Ronald Reagan. He was also part of the Western States Manpower Advisory Committee established by the US Commission on Civil Rights. During 1972-1973, Hillman was a Visiting Research Fellow at Jesus College, University of Oxford as well as a visiting distinguished professor of economics at Lincoln University in Christchurch, New Zealand in 1995-1996 and received an honorary doctorate from the University of Ceará, Brazil in 1999.

In his retirement, Hillman focused his attention on writing in both creative non-fiction and the memoir. His account of his childhood during the Depression years, under the title of Hogs, Mules and Yellow Dogs, was published by University of Arizona Press in 2012.
Hillman passed away on June 4, 2015 due to complications of a stroke.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into three series

list.item: Sub-Series I: Water and Public Policy, 1933-1990
Sub-Series II: Food and Fiber Commission, 1965-1980
Sub-Series III: University of Arizona Administration Files, 1948-1993

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Dr. Jimmye S. Hillman Papers span over the years, 1933–2007 (bulk 1960 – 1995), containing material on agricultural economics in the form of correspondence, writings, and presentations made throughout his career and lifetime. The papers highlight his involvement in the Commission on Food and Fiber and water resource policy.

item.corpname: UA College of Agriculture and Life Sciences.
United States. Agency for International Development

item.subject: Agriculture -- Economics aspects -- United States -- Congresses.

scopecontent.p: The series is comprised of files that focus on specific subjects and projects that Dr. Hillman worked on over the years.

Listed in chronological order, this subseries is comprised of papers, reports, and various correspondence related to water and public policy within the state of Arizona, along with a materials focused on the Central Arizona Project (CAP), Arizona’s single largest resource for renewable water supplies.

Salt River Project Crop and Stock Reports,

scopecontent.p: In chronological order, this subseries is comprised of reports, papers, and correspondence in relation to the President’s National Advisory Commission on Food and Fiber, which Dr. Hillman was appointed to as Executive Director during 1966 – 1967.

scopecontent.p: Arranged in chronological order, this subseries is comprised of notes, papers, correspondence focused on consulting work and various personal work that Dr. Hillman did over the years. Some of work includes the consulting work he provided for USAID in Brazil, agricultural policy advising for Portugal, chairing the President’s Commission on US-Japanese Relations, as well as his sabbatical work in New Zealand and Visiting Fellow/Professor appointments outside of the US.

scopecontent.p: The series is comprised of the scholarly activities that Dr. Hillman participated in during his career.
In chronological order, this subseries is comprised of articles, speeches, and papers written by Dr. Hillman that predominately focus on agricultural policy and tariff and trade policies.
